quoteFirst: Few are aware of the complicated means and agencies that are in constant operation on railways day and night, to ensure the safety of the passengers to their journey’s end.  The road is under a system of continuous inspection.  The railway is watched by foremen, with “gangs” of men under them, in lengths varying from
quoteLast: miles, according to circumstances.  Their continuous duty is to see that the rails and chairs are sound, their fastenings complete, and the line clear of all obstructions.
title:
Lives of the Engineers
The Locomotive.  George and Robert Stephenson
author: Smiles, Samuel, 1812-1904

title: An Old Coachman's Chatter, with Some Practical Remarks on Driving
author: Corbett, Edward, 1817-1895; Sturgess, J. (John), 1839-1903 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The accused were sixty-six in number, including eleven who were not in custody, and the pleadings occupied no less than eighteen sittings. Sentence was delivered on the 25th of July. Six of the accused were condemned to transportation;
quoteLast: years', four to two years', and five to one year's imprisonment. The remainder were acquitted. Among those sentenced to imprisonment was M.
title:
The Memoirs of François René Vicomte de Chateaubriand sometime Ambassador to England. volume 5 (of 6)
Mémoires d'outre-tombe volume 5
author: Chateaubriand, François-René, vicomte de, 1768-1848; Teixeira de Mattos, Alexander, 1865-1921 [Translator]

quoteFirst: On the north side of this river, the low land again begins, and stretches out from the foot of the mountains down to the banks of the great river; so that, before the river Turnagain, it forms a large bay, on the south side of which we were now at anchor, and where we had from
quoteLast: fathoms, from half-flood to high water.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels, Volume 16
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: “To-day ‘Mark’ and I went from Butte to Anaconda without the ladies. We left the hotel at 4:30 by trolley car in order to have plenty of time to reach the train, but we had gone only three blocks when the power gave out and we could not move. It was
quoteLast: and there was no carriage in sight. We tried to get a grocery wagon, but the mean owner refused to take us a quarter of a mile to the depot for less than ten dollars. I told him to go to ----.
title: Eccentricities of genius
author: Pond, James B. (James Burton), 1838-1903

quoteFirst: Weighing at sunrise the next day, with light winds, and charming weather, we bore away to the Carquinez Straits. This passage lies on the eastern face of San Pablo; it may be a mile and a half wide, and we found a broad ship channel, ranging from
quoteLast: fathoms soundings, all the way to the head of the straits, where we anchored the Julia, in twenty-five feet water, within a bound of the bank. Our position was at the site of an embryo city, called Benecia.
title: Los gringos; or, An inside view of Mexico and California
author: Wise, H. A. (Henry Augustus), 1819-1869

quoteFirst: But as this wind blows from Maria's Islands, it can bring no very great sea along with it; and therefore, upon the whole, this may be accounted a very safe road. The bottom is clean, good holding ground; and the depth of water from
title:
A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 15
Forming A Complete History Of The Origin And Progress Of Navigation, Discovery, And Commerce, By Sea And Land, From The Earliest Ages To The Present Time
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: New orders came, and I sent for my two sergeants and four corporals. We were ordered to fire during exactly four minutes, from one minute past
quoteLast: minutes past twelve. A supply of cartridges was placed beside each loophole, so that every soldier could fire the greatest possible number of shots in the given time. All guns were inspected.
title: Campaign diary of a French officer
author: Nicolas, René, Lieutenant; Babbitt, Katharine, 1871-1925 [Translator]
